results.title: Second chorus
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Boris Morros and H C Potter
results.brief_description: Fred Astaire leads a University orchestra and plays the trumpet while aspiring to great heights. Danny, and his friend and rival, Hank Taylor, vie for Ellen’s affections and a position with the famous Artie Shaw Band. Romance and comedy abound as the beautiful and witty Paulette Godard endeavours to influence her boss, Artie Shaw, into recruiting the talented duo.

results.title: Scrooge
results.creator_credit: Cinema Center Films, Robert H Solo and Ronald Neame
results.brief_description: This musical version of Charles Dickens’ timeless and beloved story is a lavish and lively production starring Albert Finney. Ebenezer Scrooge, the miserable old miser, takes a frightening journey through Christmas Past, Present and Yet to Come. He realizes there is still hope for his salvation on Christmas Day. He dons a Father Christmas costume and visits the home of Bob Cratchit, his loyal employee, to spread his new-found joy to the whole family, especially Tiny Tim. Music by Leslie Bricusse.

results.title: Scott of the Antarctic
results.creator_credit: Rank Film Productions, Sir Michael Balcon and Charles Frend
results.brief_description: Saga of the ill fated 1912 expedition led by Captain Robert Scott which aimed to be the first to reach the South Pole. Features John Mills, James Robertson Justice and Kenneth Moore.

results.title: Schindler's list
results.creator_credit: Universal City Studios Productions, Amblin Entertainment, Steven Spielberg, Gerald Molen and Branko Lustig
results.brief_description: Staggering adaptation of Thomas Keneally’s novel of the same name about an Austrian businessman who, during the Second World War, saved 1,100 Polish Jews from Nazi slaughter by using them in his factory manufacturing crockery for the German Army. Filmed almost entirely on location in Poland in gritty monochrome, this is a brilliantly realised, fiercely controlled and restrained treatment of a true story. Harsh and compassionate, it avoids sentimentality until the end. The three central performances, Liam Neeson who is towering as Oskar Schindler, Ben Kingsley as his Jewish accountant and Ralph Fiennes as the odious Nazi Commandant Amon Goeth, are unforgettable. Winner of seven Academy Awards for: Best Picture of the Year, Best Achievement in Directing, Best Screenplay based on Material Previously Produced or Published, Best Achievement in Cinematography, Best Achievement in Film Editing, Best Achievement in Music, and Best Production Design.

results.title: Scent of a woman
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, City Lights Films and Martin Brest
results.brief_description: It’s thanksgiving weekend in New York and Lt. Colonel Frank Slade (Al Pacino) is in town for a slice of the good life: fine cuisine, beautiful women chauffered limousines and a suite at the Waldorf-Astoria. The naive and young Charlie Simms (Chris O’Donnell) is reluctantly along for the ride, getting the education of a lifetime. Slade is one of life’s true originals, now blind, irascible yet with a touch of the poet. Charlie is an earnest young prep student facing a difficult crossroads in his life. Their raucous, revealing and at times hysterical adventure in New York will leave them both changed forever.

results.title: Scenes from a marriage
results.brief_description: A passionate, probing and honest look at a marriage, its disintegration and the relationship that follows. Liv Ullman and Erland Josephson are remarkable throughout this intimate and often painful portrait which Bergamn originally made as 6 50 minute episodes for television and subsequently edited into a full-length feature. Bergman examines the trauma of a beleagured marriage largely in close-up creating an exhaustive study of the doubt, despair, confusion and loneliness experienced by Marianne on discovering her husband’s infidelity with a younger woman. Swedish language with English subtitles.

results.title: Scarlet Street
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, Walter Wanger and Fritz Lang
results.brief_description: Lang’s darkest American film is a twisted moral tale that benefits from Edward G Robinson’s fine performance as a company man who is driven to embezzlement as a result of his passion for a scheming vixen. Lang’s impeccable shadowed visions and the air of slovenly decadence with which he surrounds the woman and her secret lover, plus the raw force of the bitter ending, set this apart from the subsequent tales of seduction by a femme fatale. Also stars Joan Bennett and Dan Durea. Based on the play La chienne by George de la Fouchardiere and previously filmed by Jean Renoir.

results.title: Scarface = the shame of a nation
results.brief_description: A detailed chronicle of the life of Chicago gangster Al Capone, played by Paul Muni, with Ann Dvorak as an incestuous sister thrown in for good measure. This brutal and graphic film was made in 1931, but its release was delayed by the censors. Based on the novel by Armitage Traill, this film is also known as “the Shame of a Nation”.

results.title: Scarface [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, Martin Bregman and Brian De Palma
results.brief_description: In Brian DePalma’s 1983 adaptation of “Scarface”, Al Pacino stars as Tony Montana, an exiled Cuban criminal who lands in Miami after Castro opened Mariel Harbour in 1980. Montana goes to work for a Miami drug lord (Robert Loggia), but soon rises to the top of Florida’s crime chain, appropriating Loggia’s coke-head mistress (Michelle Pfeiffer) in the process. Once having created a cocaine empire, Montana sees it crumbling at the edges as he descends into drug-induced paranoia, destroying all those who are close to him, and eventually himself. Features screenplay by Oliver Stone and music by Giorgio Moroder. Cast includes: Al Pacino, Steven Bauer, Michelle Pfeiffer, Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio and Robert Loggia.

results.title: Scaramouche
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Carey Wilson and George Sidney
results.brief_description: This version of Rafael Sabatini’s swashbuckler stars Stewart Granger as Andre Moreau, an 18th century French nobleman who disguises himself as an actor to revenge the death of his brother at the hands of a wicked marquis. Challenged to a sword fight by the marquis, Moreau takes refuge in a theatrical troupe, posing as the clown - Scaramouche. Being in disguise provides Moreau with the time to take fencing lessons from swordmaster Doutreval (John Dehner), as well as romancing his leading lady, Lenore (Eleanor Parker). When Moreau/Scaramouche has learnt all there is to know about fencing, it’s time to face his adversary, and there are a few surprises in store too that have nothing to do with duelling. This remake credits itself as containing the longest sword fight in cinema history. Cast also includes Janet Leigh and Mel Ferrer.
